timeline_html:
Here’s what I’m seeing: Your shedding began about 4 months before this check-in (around May 2025). The main drivers showing up are an ongoing autoimmune/thyroid flare that started in Feb, a medication change in Mar–May, and a period of acute emotional stress with no exact date given. These overlap and explain why your shedding has come in waves instead of a clear rise-and-fall.

Triggers in play:

  • 📌 Autoimmune/thyroid flare (since Feb 2025, still active) — this keeps signaling follicles to pause, so stabilization won’t fully happen until the flare calms.
  • 📌 Medication change (Mar–May 2025, still ongoing) — often peaks 1–4 months later, matching your mid-summer shedding waves.
  • 📌 Emotional stress (date not provided) — can amplify shedding but hard to time precisely here.

Worst month: Shedding was likely heaviest Jun–Jul 2025, as both the med-change lag and the thyroid flare lined up.

Onset window: May 2025 fits with the typical 2–4 month lag after your Feb–Mar triggers.

Stabilization: Because the thyroid flare is ongoing, shedding will not fully calm until ~4–8 weeks after the autoimmune activity eases. If the medication is still in use, it can also extend the shedding period.

Regrowth: Once the drivers settle, baby hairs usually start showing 6–8 weeks later. That means if the flare improves in late 2025, first fuzz should start appearing by early 2026 🌱.

Where you are now: You’re still in the peak-to-stabilization transition — shedding waves are normal with overlapping and ongoing triggers. The key is that when the thyroid/medication piece is steadier, your hair will move into its regrowth rhythm. You’re not stuck here forever ❤️.
